post_text:
Actress Lexi Underwood is the latest to join the speaker and performer lineup for the free suicide prevention training on Tuesday for California students in grades 7 to 12.

"Join me as I talk about normalizing mental health in the Black community, supporting Black youth, and my journey to joy," Lexi tweeted this week.

Your school leaders have the password to join the live event (or send us a direct message for the password). Can't make it live? Don't worry - you can watch it the next day on the LivingWorks Education YouTube channel.

Having students and teachers trained to recognize when someone is struggling and be able to connect them to help is so important, especially during the COVID-19 crisis.
Learn more at https://www.lwyouthsummit.com/.

California Department of Education #suicideprevention #SuicideAwareness #mentalhealthmatters #mentalhealth #StrongerTogether

post_text:
Some families in San Diego County may not know there‚Äôs a $1,200 Economic Impact Payment plus $500 per child available to them. Help the IRS spread the word to people who don't usually file tax returns so they don‚Äôt miss out. The non-filers tool can be used by people and families who are experiencing homelessness, low-income workers, people with no income, non-dependent students, the unbanked, and others. People can qualify for a payment even if they do not have earned income or work.
‚û°Ô∏è‚ÄºÔ∏èThe deadline to apply is Oct. 15. More information is available at https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/non-filers-enter-payment-info-here

post_text:
Tutors 4 SD was created to help students transition into the online learning environment due to #COVID19. The organization provides free, weekly one-on-one tutoring to high school and middle school students in San Diego County. Students are connected with college-level peer tutors for a one- to two-hour video chat each week.
üí°Learn more at https://www.tutors4sd.org/.

Find more mental health and wellness resources at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Health-Practices/Mental-Health-Resources

post_text:
As the pandemic and its impact on students and families continues, it's critical that children continue to receive safe, healthy food they need to learn and thrive. SDCOE will regularly update its student meal distribution sites webpage (linked below) to make sure parents and guardians know where to find and how to access free student meals.

On Aug. 31, the USDA announced it would extend the flexibility for districts and schools to feed any child, regardless of their district, at least through Dec. 31. This means that districts and schools can continue to provide free grab-and-go meals at any time, outside typical settings, and allow parents and guardians to pick up meals without the student being present.

https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/Fall-Feeding-Programs-for-San-Diego-County.aspx

Feeding San Diego County of San Diego - Government San Diego Food Bank #studentmeals #nochildhungry #sdequity #SanDiegoCounty

post_text: Elmo and his dad are back with some encouraging words for families this #backtoschool season. Some kids are learning from home, some from school, and some a mix of both. Learning transitions can be tough on students. Parents and guardians, when things get tough, take a slow, deep breath. It's going to be OK. üíõ Thanks Sesame Street!

post_text:
School district #ValleyFire update: Due to power outages and #ValleyFire evacuation orders in the Jamul and Dulzura communities of San Diego County, schools in the Jamul-Dulzura Union School District (which have been operating in the distance learning format) will be closed through Friday, Sept. 11.

For schools in the Mountain Empire Unified School District, there will not be live online instruction Wednesday, Sept. 9, due to extended power outages in parts of the community. At this time, all school and district offices will be open unless power, fire, and wind conditions dictate otherwise. Due to air quality concerns, the Mountain Empire Food Services department will not be handing out meals tomorrow. Meal service may resume Thursday.

Leadership of both districts will continue to monitor the situation and consult with local fire and utility representatives.

Updates will be posted at www.sdcoe.net when available.

#StaySafeSD #CAWildfires Jamul-Dulzura Union School District Mountain Empire Unified School District

SDCOE.NET

For schools in the Mountain Empire Unified School District, there will not be live online instruction Wednesday, Sept. 9, due to extended power outages in parts of the community. At this time, all school and district offices will be open unless power, fire, and wind conditions dictate otherwise. post_text:
So the beginning of the school year isn't exactly what everyone was hoping. But we can get through this, San Diego County. It may look different, but the work is the same. Our San Diego County Superintendent of Schools Dr. Paul Gothold says it well: "At the end of the day, we provide education, support, and every resource possible to our students and we will continue to do so."
Parents, family members and caregivers, we know you're working hard to help your child be a student from home. And teachers, principals, and school staff, we know you're are trying to make this start to the 2020 school year the best experience you can for students. Together, we got this, and we'll get through this.

Show less

post_text:
Cox Communications is suspending late fees and extending payment relief offerings through June 2021 for customers in the company's low-cost internet program Connect2Compete who express an inability to pay due to pandemic hardships.
The company also recently announced a new offer for qualifying families who sign up between July 21 and Sept. 30 to receive Connect2Compete free for two months including free remote technical support in time for #backtoschool. Families can qualify for Connect2Compete easily from their mobile device or desktop by visiting www.cox.com/c2c.
Learn more: https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/Cox-Expands-Commitment-to-Bridging-the-Learning-Divide.aspx

post_text:
There's no guide for parenting, teaching, working, going to school, and living in a pandemic. But when you're feeling burned out, stressed, and overwhelmed, here are some ways to practice gratitude. Give it a try - it just might help.
üåàNotice the good things in life, look for them, appreciate them. ‚Å†
‚è≤Ô∏èTake time in your week to think of people, places, and things you are grateful for. ‚Å†
üìùStart a gratitude journal and when you commit to writing down good things, you are more likely to notice good things. ‚Å†
üõèÔ∏èPractice gratitude rituals, such as naming the people or things you appreciate and are grateful for before a meal or before bedtime. ‚Å†
üíõShow your appreciation for someone by paying it forward or telling people how you feel and what they mean to you. ‚Å†
‚Å†
You can start by commenting on this post with something you're grateful for.

üîóFind more mental health resources for students and adults at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Health-Practices/Mental-Health-Resources
#gratitude #backtoschool2020 #firstdayofschool #MentalHealthMatters #thursdaytip

post_text:
We're in the final 29 days to complete the census. If you've already completed your census form, then text a friend, post a story, share this video, ask your neighbor -- do what you can to make sure every person gets counted. It's super important! Census data is used to determine the placement of more than $7 billion dollars a year to California in federal funding for schools. These funds are for special education, school nutrition programs, Head Start, afterschool, and migrant education programs.
It only takes a few minutes and answering the easy and confidential questions supports better schools, food assistance programs, and emergency services locally. Everyone counts and there is no citizenship question. Take the census online at my2020census.gov, by phone at 844-330-2020, or mail in your form.

Headed into this week ready for anything -- just like Zaneta, a new pre-K student whose mom and dad work at the San Diego County Office of Education.
Sometimes life throws everything at you, but all you can do is prepare the best you can and then be ready to adjust when plans change. Everything may look different, but the work is the same.
So grab your face mask, glasses, hat, binoculars, boots, superwoman shirt, and anything else you might need, because Monday, we're ready for you! üí™üèΩ
#COVID19 #InThisTogether #mondaymotivation #backtoschool2020 #firstdayofschool

post_text:
The County of San Diego Registrar of Voters has launched a #VoteSaferSD student art project. Students can use their passion for the arts and civic engagement to create public service announcements that will help spread the word about new voting safety measures during #COVID19 for the Nov. 3 Presidential General Election. This year, every active registered voter will receive a ballot in the mail as a safety measure during the pandemic.
Student designs can be flyers or social media graphics. Get the details and information today because the deadline to submit is Sept. 9.
https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/votesafersd.aspx
County of San Diego - Government #history #socialscience #civicengagement #vapa

post_text:
When one stressful thing piles on top of another (and another, and another in some cases -- like starting the school year virtually during a pandemic), something as simple as gratitude has been shown to help. Whether you're a student, teacher, parent, or administrator taking time each day to look for, notice, and appreciate good things - no matter how small - can make a big difference.
Why does gratitude matter?‚Å†
üîäGratitude amplifies the good. ‚Å†
üëèüèΩGratitude allows celebration of the present. ‚Å†
üö´Gratitude blocks toxic emotions such as envy, resentment, regret, depression. ‚Å†
üí™üèΩGratitude strengthens social ties and self-worth. ‚Å†
üåàGrateful people are more stress resilient (and who doesn't need some of that right now).
Find more mental health resources at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Health-Practices/Mental-Health-Resources

#ThankfulThursday #ThursdayThoughts #gratitude #mentalhealth

post_text:
Now that the County of San Diego has been removed from the state‚Äôs COVID-19 watchlist, you may be wondering what that means for local schools.

While this is encouraging news that could help pave the way for us to reopening school campuses this fall, there are also some important things to keep in mind. These numbers will need to stay within the acceptable range for at least 14 days before schools in San Diego County will be allowed to reopen without a waiver. Even if schools are allowed to return to in-person instruction, it doesn‚Äôt mean that they will right away. Schools must follow guidance from the California Department of Public Health and comply with the local public health order requiring creation and posting of a Safe Reopening Plan before being allowed to reopen.

Even if schools are allowed to return to in-person instruction, it doesn‚Äôt mean that they will right away. Schools must follow guidance from the California Department of Public Health and comply with the local public health order requiring creation and posting of a Safe Reopening Plan before being allowed to reopen.

What are the state requirements to reopen schools in San Diego County? What's an elementary school waiver? Can schools be closed after getting the green light to reopen?
There's been what feels like constantly changing information regarding COVID-19, safety measures, and school closures since mid-March.
Here are some answers as we know them as of Aug. 14. SDCOE will continue to post new information as it becomes available, so you can make the best decisions to keep your family safe and healthy during this pandemic.

What are the state requirements to reopen schools in San Diego County? What's an elementary school waiver? Can schools be closed after getting the green light to reopen?
There's been what feels like constantly changing information regarding COVID-19, safety measures, and school closures since mid-March.
Here are some answers as we know them as of Aug. 14. SDCOE will continue to post new information as it becomes available, so you can make the best decisions to keep your family safe and healthy during this pandemic.

post_text:
Tate McRae, Lavendaire, Emma Benoit (My Ascension) have just been announced as part of the virtual LivingWorks Education Youth Summit on Sept. 15 for all middle and high school students in California. This suicide prevention training for students is part of a free online program launched this year by California Department of Education and the San Diego County Office of Education.
Especially during the #COVID19 pandemic, having students and teachers trained to recognize when someone is struggling and connect them to help empowers the whole school community to come together and support those at risk.
Learn more about the event at www.lwyouthsummit.com and educators look for a code next month to distribute to students next month.
‚û°Ô∏èIn the meantime, save the date (Sept. 15 from 1 to 2 p.m.) on your calendar and spread the word about this event using the images below.

#suicideprevention #suicidepreventiontraining #students #middleschool #highschool

post_text:
Back to school, back to work, at home or in-person -- no matter how it looks for you, it's probably stressful. So let's be kind to our students, teachers, and parents, and ourselves. This time is challenging and scary, and each day in a pandemic takes courage.‚Å†
If your expectations don't match how you feel right now, you are not failing and you are not alone. No one knows how to do this perfectly. The most you can do is your best, and that‚Äôs enough. Comment with a üíó or with an affirmation that has worked for you during COVID-19. ‚Å†
‚Å†
*Thanks to our SDCOE employees (pictured here) who are working at our Linda Vista campus making sure essential work gets done and that we are as safe as possible while doing it in-person. üëèüèΩ You can find more information about available services at www.sdcoe.net.

SDCOE's School Safety Coordinator Tim Ware has been in the county's Emergency Operations Center as the educational liaison since schools and businesses closed in mid-March to prevent the spread of #COVID19.
He relays timely information to SDCOE leadership and ensures county and sector representatives have insight into district and school operations.
Tim has been working with others in the EOC to gather and share resources and supports for food distribution, medical updates, child care, law enforcement, personal protective equipment, transportation, and more, for students and families.
A big thank you to Tim for his service, as well as the other representatives in the county's EOC working to keep our residents safe and healthy during an unprecedented pandemic üëèüèæüëèüèæüëèüèΩüëèüèºüëèüèªüëè

post_text:
Help our region's Monarch School San Diego, which educates students impacted by homelessness, to double a $5,000 donation from local company Cavignac & Associates! All you have to do is click this link (www.agentgiving.com/cavignac-associates/) and then share the story using the Facebook button on the left.

Cavignac & Associates earned the 2020 Make More Happen Award for its volunteer work with Monarch School and its commitment to improving the local community. The award, sponsored by Liberty Mutual Insurance and Safeco Insurance, includes a $5,000 donation with a chance to double the amount to $10,000, all of which will go directly to Monarch, the largest and most comprehensive program of its kind for students impacted by homelessness.

Thank you for your help!

By joining thousands of San Diego readers this summer, you can help support San Diego Public Library youth programming. There's one month left of the San Diego Central Library SDPL Stay-In Summer Reading Club City of San Diego virtual summer reading program. You can sign up today to log any reading you've done since June 1. If the San Diego Public Library meets it's community reading goal of 200,000 books by the end of August, then the San Diego Public Library Foundation and Intuit will donate $10,000 to youth programming.
Read 10 books or for 10 hours to collect prizes, and complete fun at-home activities to earn digital badges.
Learn more: https://www.sandiego.gov/public-library/kidsandteens/summerreading
Sign up: https://sandiego.beanstack.org/reader365

post_text:
We need our communities to help lower the number of COVID-19 cases in the area so schools can reopen safely for in-person instruction. Together, we can #SaveOurSchoolYear in San Diego County.
‚Å†
Due to the region's high COVID-19 case rate, the county was placed on the state's monitoring list in early July. The only way schools can reopen with in-person instruction is if the county meets the state's requirements and stays off the monitoring list for at least 14 days. ‚Å†
‚Å†
You can help! Wear a face mask, avoid gatherings, maintain 6 feet distance from anyone outside your household, and wash your hands thoroughly. Together, we can slow the spread of COVID-19 and make it possible for schools to reopen for in-person instruction safely.‚Å†
‚Å†
(Thanks to Merced Union High School District for the post inspiration.)‚Å†
‚Å†
#SanDiegoCounty #COVID19 #staysafe #flattenthecurve County of San Diego - Government County of San Diego Health and Human Services Agency

post_text:
Here are 9 tips that can help parents support their students when class is back in session through distance learning. Last week's announcement from the state that all schools on the state's watch list would have to start with distance learning was tough to hear. Students need to be in school and teachers and administrators can't wait to welcome them back. Everyone has been looking for something normal in this strange time. SDCOE will keep doing the work to support educators so they can confidently provide high-quality learning whether it's from a distance or in-person.
Find more resources for parents at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Parent-Resources.
#parenting #distancelearning #remoteteaching #remotelearning

post_text:
Parents can have a say in their district's distance learning plans and how schools will address learning loss with the new Learning Continuity and Attendance Plan. It's this year's shortened version of the Local Control and Accountability Plan. Districts must reach out to parents and then present the plan at two public hearings with adoption by Sept. 30.
Families know what worked and what was a challenge during the sudden shift to distance or remote learning in the spring and can offer advice from their perspective. Learn more about districts' required distance learning plans.
https://edsource.org/2020/parents-must-have-a-say-in-districts-distance-learning-plans-under-new-california-law/636182

Tomorrow (July 15) is the deadline for families to apply for pandemic food benefits for children!
Spread the word: Students who receive free or reduced price meals at school are eligible for up to $365 for groceries through the state #COVID19 pandemic electronic benefit transfer (P-EBT) program. This is in addition to grab-and-go meals provided by schools and summer feeding programs.
‚≠êÔ∏è Learn more and apply at https://ca.p-ebt.org/en/ ‚≠êÔ∏è‚Å†
San Diego Hunger Coalition estimates 250,000 San Diego County students are eligible for this benefit, and we appreciate you sharing this important information.
If you have already received your PEBT card, you do not need to apply.

#nochildhungry #studentmeals #pandemic #support #parenting #families #california

Essential SDCOE employees have been keeping operations running smoothly since our campus closed in March to prevent #COVID19, but today we welcomed back a new group of employees. Our teams have been working to make it safe for more employees to be back in the office and open the main campus to visitors. Beginning this week, visitors will be allowed onsite by appointment only for essential services. Be sure to call ahead, and then bring your face mask to check in at the front gate. To find contacts and phone numbers for what you need, visit the SDCOE homepage at https://www.sdcoe.net/Pages/Home.aspx.
#reopening #staysafe #thankanessentialemployee #inittogether

post_text:
More than 22,000 school-age children in San Diego County have been identified as homeless, and this population has been especially impacted by the school and business closures resulting from the #COVID19 #pandemic. SDCOE and San Diego County Credit Union ‚Äì along with iHeartMedia Inc. ‚Äì aim to collect online donations to purchase much-needed pencils, pens, binders, crayons, backpacks, and more during the SDCCU Stuff the Bus campaign. Just $20 can be a new backpack filled with supplies for a student experiencing homelessness -- and be one less thing for them to worry about.
Learn more and donate through July at: https://charity.gofundme.com/o/en/campaign/stuff-the-bus-2020.
#stuffthebus Star941 Jamn957 Channel933

It's important that the #2020Census counts all Californians, no matter who they are or their background. The census data will be used to impact the next generation by informing funding decisions on special education, teacher training, youth programs and more. By filling out your census form, you're giving California‚Äôs kids a brighter future.
‚≠êÔ∏è The census is completely confidential, so your personal information cannot be shared with the courts, police, immigration enforcement, your landlord, or your employer.
Fill out your census form today at https://my2020census.gov/.
Learn more from California Census.
#CaliforniaForAll #MakeItCountMonday #ICount

San Diego County Office of Education added 8 new photos.
June 25 ¬∑

Reopening schools following closures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 is complicated, so we put together some questions and answers to help. Reopening campuses will require a lot of planning and preparation, as well as funding for expenses that would not have been needed before the pandemic. To learn more about what school might look like in the fall, take a look at SDCOE's Recovery and Reopening Plan guidance at
https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Reopening-Plan. It has practical, detailed instructions on how to prepare schools for reopening.

post_text:
#ThankfulThursday
To the people who have been on the front lines of the #COVID19 crisis from day one, thank you!
We know it's stressful and scary being out and uncomfortable to wear a mask for hours, but we appreciate you!
Since March 16, the San Diego County districts and schools have served more than 5 million student meals and San Diego Unified School District has distributed 2.5 million of those meals.
These photos are courtesy of San Diego Unified School District which kicked off its summer meals program this week with a modified street fair. For a list of summer meal programs across the county in English and Spanish go to http://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/Summer-Feeding-Programs-for-San-Diego-County--.aspx.
Important reminders:
‚≠êMeals are available for all children, ages 2-18, no verification, ID, or registration needed.
‚≠êChildren do not have to attend a particular school to receive meals at that location.
‚≠êChildren do not have to be present for parents to pick up meals for their kids.

post_text:
The P-EBT application deadline has been extended to July 15!
Spread the word: Students who receive free or reduced price meals at school are eligible for up to $365 for groceries through the state #COVID19 pandemic electronic benefit transfer (P-EBT) program. This is in addition to grab-and-go meals provided by schools and summer feeding programs. ‚≠êÔ∏è Learn more and apply at https://ca.p-ebt.org/en/. ‚Å†
If you have already received you PEBT card, you do not need to apply. ‚Å†
San Diego Hunger Coalition estimates 250,000 San Diego County students are eligible for this benefit, so please help spread the word! ‚Å†

#nochildhungry #studentmeals #pandemic #support #parenting #families #california

post_text:
To all the dads and people who are loved like a father, happy Father‚Äôs Day!
It‚Äôs been a tough few months during #COVID19, but you‚Äôve risen to the challenge. We see you, dads, home schooling the kids from makeshift desks, managing the added stress and worry for your family, going full speed from morning to night during this strange, difficult time.
We hope today is filled with love! (and maybe a nap)üò¥üí§ Here are some pics of dads who are SDCOE employees and their beautiful families.
üì∏ Rod Magdaluyo on the iTV team who is usually behind the camera pictured with two of his daughters.
‚úèÔ∏è Charles Muhammad who teaches students experiencing homelessness at Monarch School San Diego pictured with his family.
üíª Mark Bandala who has three boys and is part of the Integrated Technology Services team.
üéí And Dr. Oscar Felix, the North Region Juvenile Court and Community Schools principal who also has two daughters. üéä Happy Father‚Äôs Day!

Do you know someone who's shown extraordinary courage this year? A person committed to creating safer, stronger communities and helping those who need it most?
The American Red Cross of San Diego and Imperial Counties is currently seeking nominations for the 18th annual Real Heroes Awards in September. These awards celebrate ordinary, exceptional people in the following categories:
Animal Welfare Hero
Community Partner Hero
Fire and Rescue Hero
Gift of Life ‚Äì Blood Donor Hero
Good Samaritan Hero
Law Enforcement Hero
Military Hero
Youth Good Samaritan Hero (age 18 or younger)
If you know someone, submit a nomination by July 10:
https://www.redcross.org/local/california/southern-california/about-us/news-and-events/events/Annual-Real-Heroes-Breakfast.html

post_text:
A new framework from the San Diego County Office of Education can help provide insight into specific actions schools could take to keep students and staff safe in the fall.
Based on state and local guidance and developed in consultation with subject matter experts and stakeholders, SDCOE's Recovery and Reopening Plan provides districts and schools with detailed, practical instructions on how to prepare schools for reopening after the closures resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Learn more and view the plan at https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/SDCOE-Announces-Reopening-Guidance.aspx.
#COVID19 #reopeningschools #staysafe

post_text:
The SDCountyHHSA has changed the school-related portions of the local public health order that‚Äôs in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
All public, charter, and private schools may hold classes or school business operations on the school campus, provided the school complies with the measures in state health and education guidance.
The order also states that each school shall complete and post a document detailing the actions the school is taking to comply with the California Department of Public Health Industry Guidance measures after considering the California Department of Education Guidelines (see previous posts for links to those documents).
SDCOE staff are reviewing and analyzing the new state guidance with the local health order to put together support for local districts and schools to reopen in a way that‚Äôs safe for students and staff.
Read the updated order at https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/dam/sdc/hhsa/programs/phs/Epidemiology/HealthOfficerOrderCOVID19.pdf

Recent graduate Ydania "Penny" Penaloza and San Diego County Superintendent of Schools Dr. Paul Gothold will be speaking in today's live graduation/promotion ceremony for K-12 students in the 79th assembly district at 3 p.m. on Assemblymember Shirley Weber‚Äôs Facebook page at http://facebook.com/ShirleyWeberCaliforniaStateAssembly. ‚Å†

Below are the opening lines from Penny's powerful and passionate speech (more in stories). Don‚Äôt miss the rest! Head to Dr. Weber‚Äôs page to watch the ceremony live from 3-4:30 p.m. today.

"I am the proud ambassador and representative of Lindsay Community School, and young women everywhere graduating today. I am also the mother of my amazing 4-year-old daughter Rosemary."

Explore your world thinking like a reader! Reading is critical to academic success and reading during the summer can help students keep and boost their literacy skills. Books can help students see the world from someone else‚Äôs perspective and also see themselves reflected in the story.
Enjoy this week‚Äôs Learning at Home Bingo from SDCOE curriculum experts and The San Diego Union-Tribune. Don‚Äôt have a book you‚Äôd like to read, check out e-books and audiobooks from San Diego County Library with an e-card.
Find previous Learning at Home Bingos at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Distance-Learning/Learning-at-Home-Bingo.

#distancelearning #literacy #summerreading

The California Department of Public Health released new guidance today on reopening schools. While we don't have answers tonight on what that means for schools locally, the San Diego County Office of Education will carefully review the information and consult with local public health officials.
SDCOE will continue to share information as it becomes available.
The COVID-19 Industry Guidance for Schools and School-Based Programs can be found at https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-schools.pdf.
Links to all the new industry guidance released today is available at: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR20-113.aspx

Congratulations to San Diego County's Class of 2020! We can't wait to see what you do.
Whether your graduation or promotion ceremony is at home with family, in a car at a drive-in or in a drive-thru, or something in between, we know you worked so hard and overcame so many obstacles to get to this place. You are strong, creative, brave, and amazing.
These photos are of SDCOE families and their seniors, and of graduation ceremonies across the county. Tag us in your photos if you'd like to share your experience here.

post_text:
Interested in working at a school or district in San Diego County? This is an unprecedented time in education, but hiring is still happening.
Job seekers can connect with San Diego County school employers, receive credential advisement, and maybe even receive a job offer on the spot at the SDCOE Virtual Teacher Job Fair tomorrow from 3 to 6 p.m. Register at https://thecentervirtualevents-sdcoe.vfairs.com/.

The job fair is ideal for credentialed teachers, those looking to change careers, recent college graduates, military veterans, those with provisional internship and short-term staff permits, substitute teachers, current university and community college students, school nurses and counselors, instructional aides, and other support employees.

post_text:
Children are probably already more aware of race, class, and gender differences than adults realize. And while it may seem too chaotic or stressful with the pandemic and recent, racially charged incidents, this can be a time to teach children about social justice, and help process how painful these events can be for them, and for you.
Talking about race can be scary -- this article has helpful suggestions for parents searching for away to have critical conversations with their children. https://www.gse.upenn.edu/news/talking-children-after-racial-incidents

All middle and high school students are invited to SDCOE's Virtual Youth Leadership Conference for access to workshops on creative arts, leadership, college readiness, reducing stress and anxiety, and more.
In a recent survey, students told our Safety and Student Engagement team that they'd like more access to online activities and resources around things that would help them during #COVID19 school closures.
Next week's virtual conference is open to any interested students and their parents. For more details and to register for the links to join in visit https://www.sdfnl.net/vlc.

South Korea, Belgium, and some other countries are slowly reopening schools and Reuters photos from this month show some of the safety measures in place to protect students and staff from contracting the virus.
We know the next school year will look different to prevent the spread of COVID-19, but seeing these images probably brings up some strong emotions for families and school staff. As SDCOE teams and district and school leaders work on reopening plans, we'll continue to post and share any updates.

#COVID19 #schoolclosures #reopeningschools

post_text:
San Diego County schools have provided more than 3 million student meals since schools closed to prevent the spread of #COVID19. Providing this basic need has been a top priority, and districts and schools continue to provide food in the ways that best meet their students' needs. Thanks to the school nutrition staff for preparing and distributing meals, community partners like Feeding San Diego and the San Diego Food Bank who have helped Juvenile Court and Community School students make their own meals, and businesses like Bay Park Fish Company, Buona Forchetta, and Top Notch School Lunches for making sure students experiencing homelessness at Monarch School San Diego have prepared meals.
For more on San Diego County student meal efforts visit: https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/food-service-for-students-continues-3M-meals-served.aspx.
shared_text:
Monarch School San Diego
May 21 at 12:10 PM ¬∑

Thank you to our generous community partners who continue to provide fresh meals for our families, many of whom do not have the ability to make meals while sheltering in place. We appreciate your support! Top Notch School Lunches, Buona Forchetta, Bay Park Fish Company

If you're looking for #STEM learning resources for your student to mark the birthday of Dr. Sally Ride, the first American woman to fly in space, visit: https://sallyridescience.ucsd.edu/about/stem-resources/ from Sally Ride Science at UC San Diego.

Especially lately, it can be easy to feel like you're not doing enough. There aren't enough hours in the day, you don't have the motivation, or you're just feeling worn down. It's been 10 weeks of #COVID19 #quarantine and stay home orders. That's a long time to live with worry, stress, and uncertainty. It's OK to not feel OK sometimes. Just know that you're doing enough and we appreciate you üåà‚òÄÔ∏èüíö

What's one thing you've done with love lately? Share in the comments and tag someone who might need to hear this today‚Å†. ü§ó
#FridayFeeling #mentalhealthmatters

What does the safe reopening of schools look like in fall 2020? The California Department of Education hosted a discussion with some school certificated and classified staff members, San Diego Unified School District Superintendent Cindy Marten, and state health officials yesterday to look at how we can keep our students, staff members, and families safe while providing high-quality education for every child. If you're interested, this video may provide some insights into the coming school year.

post_text:
#AtHomeWithSDCOE
Hi, I'm Susie and I am so grateful to be able to continue working as the homeless liaison during this critical time for vulnerable students -- although it can be hard and sometimes sad to navigate this new world of work. Currently, I am at my home that I share with my wife who is an elementary physical education teacher, our grumpy cat, Indiana, and our relatively new puppy, Bella. Bella is definitely the happiest about the situation! Our house is small so I am often navigating Zoom meetings with Amber creating exercise videos, games, and connecting with her kids nearby. I appreciate the opportunity to get a better view of her work and for her to see mine. Ultimately, I feel that we are incredibly lucky to be healthy and working; and this, like all things, will pass.

#COVID19 #educators #studentsexperiencinghomelessness #quarantinelife #quarantinepets

Kids may not recognize they're feeling stressed or be able to talk about it. Teens could withdraw, toddlers can regress, elementary kids could get headaches. Everyone reacts to stress differently. Find insights, help, and support in the Office of the California Surgeon General's Playbook: Stress Relief for Caregivers and Kids during COVID-19 at ow.ly/GsfA50zGB5Z.
üëâFind translated versions of the playbook at the bottom of https://covid19.ca.gov/manage-stress-for-health/.

#mentalhealth #mentalhealthawareness #mentalhealthawarenessmonth

How are elementary school leaders preparing for the 2020-21 school year or summer learning? One way is by working through the tough questions.

SDCOE has put together frameworks to help elementary, middle, high, and alternative school leaders think through how to do all the usual things -- registering new students, course selection, professional learning for teachers and staff -- differently during #COVID19. This is another tool for leaders to use while considering #distancelearning models.

See what questions leaders are considering in the elementary school framework link (below): https://docs.google.com/document/d/1V_nUjmJFz88QJoMgs3Jp2e1AQ4CnA3EQW2J31OjYtaw/edit
Find all the school frameworks under the "Toolkits: Planning for Learning Continuity" tab: https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Administrators

‚òÄÔ∏è Promote a growth mindset
üíú Establish routines and intentionality
üíô Model the behavior your seek
üíö Help your child express and name emotions
üíõ Commit acts of service or kindness for others
üß° Practice active listening
‚ù§Ô∏è Integrate social-emotional learning daily
‚≠êÔ∏è Celebrate what you can

post_text:
The Library of Congress has activities for kids, a writing challenge for teens, office hours for educators, and the opportunity to be a document detective and make the collections accessible for everyone. Plus interesting videos on its Facebook page bring a new perspective to the #COVID19 pandemic, like this one with NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration astronaut and scientist Kate Greene.
Find more at https://www.loc.gov/engage/.
shared_text:
The Library of Congress
May 14 at 4:00 PM ¬∑

As part of our "National Book Festival Presents" series, NASA astronaut and scientist Kate Greene discusses her forthcoming book, ‚ÄúOnce Upon a Time I Lived on Mars: Space, Exploration and Life on Earth,‚Äù with the Library's Marie Arana.

Greene lived in a simulated Martian environment located on the slopes of Mauna Loa in Hawai‚Äôi and spent several months in isolation, doing research. She has a lot to say about the stress, loneliness and other challenges of sequestration ‚Äî and all from a very novel and unique perspective.

San Diego County Office of Education added a new photo.
May 14 at 8:42 AM ¬∑

Students who are experiencing homelessness, from a low-income household, in foster care, or dealing with trauma may find online video meetings uncomfortable, scary, or embarrassing. They are being asked to bring teachers and other students into their homes and personal spaces like never before and that can bring up vulnerabilities and challenges.
Here are some ways teachers can identify vulnerable students, and then respond with compassion and support.
Find this and other social-emotional learning and mental health support tools at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Health-Practices/Mental-Health-Resources.

#mentalhealthmatters #vulnerablestudents #COVID19 California Department of Education #socialemotional

SDCOE has hosted 3,396 Zoom meetings for a total of 1,285,192 meeting minutes with 34,496 participants ü§Ø from March 16 to May 1. That's an average 70 meetings a day!
SDCOE team members are regularly in touch with the administrators and educators we support because we care so much about students that we ultimately serve. This is an unprecedented time, but SDCOE hasn't hesitated to jump to this new challenge.
Need support? There's probably a Zoom meeting scheduled for that topic. Head over to www.sdcoe.net to find it.

post_text:
Many of the ceremonies and celebrations that mark kids' journey through adolescence are in the spring, and those rites of passage have been disrupted due to COVID-19.

"Performances and proms, championships and final projects all showcase growth and learning and accomplishment. And, of course, there is graduation. These important ceremonies that say 'Look at you! You are growing up! We are so proud of you!' have been canceled, leaving kids with no closure."

It's tough to not be able to fix it, but here are some ways parents and families can help teens grieve.

https://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/how_to_help_teens_handle_the_loss_of_proms_and_graduations?
#Classof2020 #middleschool #highschool #teenagers #COVID19 #graduation #prom

GREATERGOOD.BERKELEY.EDU
How to Help Teens Handle the Loss of Proms and Graduations

post_text:
Distance learning is more than just moving school and district operations online.
To support K-12 leaders as they quickly shift and pivot during this pandemic, the San Diego County Office of Education teams have been creating support resources and tools to help district and school administrators think through this year, summer learning and next school year -- and make sure each and every student has access to quality learning experiences and the necessary support to engage in those powerful learning opportunities. View more at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Distance-Learning.
#COVID19 #leadingfromhome #learningfromhome #educationalequity

post_text:
San Diego County Superintendent of Schools Dr. Paul Gothold today urged the governor and legislature to prioritize schools in the next state budget after the California Department of Finance announced a $54.3 billion deficit due to the COVID-19 pandemic‚Äôs impact on the economy.

School district costs naturally rise by about 4% each year, so even flat funding erodes schools' purchasing power. A cut would be catastrophic at a time when our students need additional services to accelerate learning and address social-emotional and mental health.

Read Dr. Gothold‚Äôs full statement at https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/2020-05-07-County-Superintendent-Statement-Budget-Shortfall.aspx.

#COVID19 #schoolclosures #caedchat #students

post_text:
If you were wondering, schools will not be part of the state‚Äôs move into Stage 2 of modifying the stay-at-home order on Friday, May 8.

Today Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that based on the state‚Äôs progress in testing capacity and personal protective equipment inventory, California can gradually begin to move into Stage 2 this Friday with guidelines released Thursday, May 7. This includes some retail and manufacturing sectors where there‚Äôs a lower risk of transmission and they will be able to adapt and re-open with modifications.

The announcement for Friday does not include schools. As Newsom noted last week, the state is working with school districts and the California education community to determine how best to safely reopen schools. That continues to be the case.

SDCOE has been updating its assumptions and guidance for reopening schools and recently rolled out frameworks to help K-12 school leaders plan for summer and fall learning. Learn more at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net.

post_text:
Children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals at school will get extra food benefits this month through a new food assistance program. Families will begin to receive their pandemic electronic benefit transfer (P-EBT) cards in the mail in mid-May.
P-EBT benefits are in addition to the grab-and-go meals provided by schools and will help families in California buy food when school is closed.
Get more information in the FAQs provided by the California Department of Social Services at https://www.cdss.ca.gov/home/pandemic-ebt.

#studentmeals #pandemic #COVID19 #nochildhungry

post_text:
Every year on #SchoolLunchHeroDay we say thank you to the people who provide such an essential service to our students.
This year, when COVID-19 closed schools ‚Äì severing the connection many students have to a place that means safety, love, and community ‚Äì school food service and nutrition employees stepped up in a tremendous way.
They‚Äôve been outside nearly every day in rain and storms, sunshine, and heat, with a smile, a wave, a welcome, and also with meals. In San Diego County there have been nearly 2 million meals served since March 16. ‚ù§Ô∏è
When they were called on during a pandemic to serve, they did ‚Äì with courage, grace, and bravery, armed with masks and desire to help. And that is truly heroic.
üåü‚≠êÔ∏èüí•Comment and tag a school lunch hero in your life to make sure they feel the appreciation today.

post_text:
Did you hear Gov. Gavin Newsom's comments yesterday about opening schools early and wonder what that will mean for San Diego County campuses?

While there hasn't been any official guidance from the governor or California Department of Education, we have been advising local school districts and charter schools to plan for every scenario, which now includes considering the possibility of starting the 2020-21 school year as early as July or August. For some San Diego County school districts, that is already planned; a number are set to begin the 2021-20 school year on July 20.

Gov. Newsom said in his press conference that the state's recovery plan be driven by data, not dates. The same is true for schools. As we get additional guidance from the state and local public health, we will make determinations around reopening. It's important to note that school calendars are negotiated items that take a great deal of planning and coordination; moving a school start date is a complicated prospect.

‚ÄúIt is a privilege to be able to be of service during a crisis. To have people express their gratitude and bless you as they drive away is something that still makes a knot in my throat and I only wish I could do more. I‚Äôm just trying to be, as Mr. Rogers would say, a ‚Äòhelper.‚Äô ü•∞
Mr. Rogers said that when he was a boy and saw scary things in the news, his mother would say, ‚ÄúLook for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.‚Äù üíó
‚Äî Thank you to Lucero, an SDCOE food service employee and helper extraordinaire, for sharing these heartfelt words. She is pictured here helping Alpine School District #alpineschools prep meals for students in need in early April.

Reminder that May 1 is School Lunch Hero Day and this year more than most, our school food and school nutrition employees have really earned their essential workers badge.

#schoollunchheroday #schoollunchheroes #thankaschoolemployee #essentialworker #COVID19 #InItTogether #thankahelper

The SDCOE Communications team closed out the week in true work-from-home, COVID-19 fashion: a Zoom meeting interrupted by their kids.
Comment with a üëç if you can relate üòä
We see you, parents and guardians who are working from home with kids! Because we are you. üòÑ
The San Diego County Office of Education has more than 1,000 employees ‚Äî on their own, with their family, worried about loved ones ‚Äî who are trying to navigate this new normal while also doing whatever they can to support San Diego County‚Äôs students.
Some days are easier than others, but you‚Äôve made it through six weeks of school closures, social distancing, mask wearing, student meal providing, distance learning, remote teaching, and staying home. And that‚Äôs a job well done. üëç
Hope you have a great weekend!

#WFH #InItTogether #AtHomeWithSDCOE #TogetherAtHome #TeamSDCOE

post_text:
Dedicated and determined school employees have prepped, distributed, and delivered more than 1 million student meals across San Diego County.
When schools closed due to #COVID19 five weeks ago, K-12 leaders made sure getting food to students in need was a top priority.
Whether it's raining or sunny, exercising the latest public health precautions, hundreds of district and school employees have been on the frontline for this essential service.
We know there are kids out there who might be hungry or worried about their next meal. So please spread the word: Any child from age 2 to 18 can go to any student meal provider to get free breakfast and lunch. Find updated locations at www.sdcoe.net/studentmeals.

#studentmeals #mealsforkids #nochildhungry #COVID19 #pandemic #everydayheroes #schoolemployees #SanDiegoCounty #students

shared_text:
San Diego County Office of Education added a new photo.
April 14 at 12:37 PM ¬∑

Learning at Home bingo is a new tech-free resource from the San Diego County Office of Education and the The San Diego Union-Tribune. You might have seen this in the Local section of the Sunday edition, but there are also daily distance learning columns in the paper.

"Our mission at SDCOE is 'Inspiring innovation in education,'" said San Diego County Superintendent of Schools Dr. Paul Gothold. "That doesn‚Äôt just mean we push technology into classrooms. It means we solve problems and work creatively to address challenges that keep students from getting what they need and deserve to succeed in life. In this case, the pandemic has closed campuses across San Diego County, but learning still needs to happen. We want to encourage students and families to continue learning with opportunities that support classroom culture and family engagement."

Learn more: https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/SDCOE-UT-Learning-at-Home-Bingo.aspx

post_text:
When schools closed to prevent the spread of COVID-19, SDCOE's PASS AmeriCorps program members shifted from directly helping students to supporting local food banks, meal packaging, and meal distribution.
In the past four weeks, our 39 members have packaged and distribute 112,119 meals, 200 learning packets, and 750 devices. They've also called families to do wellness checks and supported teachers in virtual classrooms.
These young people continue to give back to their community and make a huge difference in the lives of students.

#thankyou #thankanessentialworker California Volunteers, Office of the Governor #studentmeals #nochildhungry #InItTogether #COVID19edu

post_text:
Kids need adults to continue reporting suspected child abuse and neglect during this #COVID19 crisis! üëáüëáüëá
Not being at school creates barriers to reporting abuse, and we know that in times of crisis, child abuse and neglect rates increase. But since schools have been closed, reports of abuse have declined dramatically in San Diego County.
This is a difficult time for everyone, but together, educators, counselors, nutrition staff, and others can continue being the person that children can depend on to help them. You may be the only person to act.

Read, share, print, post -- let's get this information out so no child has to suffer alone. ‚ù§Ô∏è

#InItTogether #mandatedreporter #schoolclosures #stopchildabuse #childabuse County of San Diego - Government County Of San Diego HHSA #speakup California Department of Education #SanDiegoCounty

post_text:
Headed out for another neighborhood walk? Give your strolls a jolt of fun with resources from the San Diego Natural History Museum. Find nature scavenger hunt ideas and printables, get help identifying local plants and animals, and access three-minute videos on natural history topics in an easy-to-understand format.
Museums, San Diego County Library, San Diego Botanical Gardens and the San Diego Zoo may be closed, but there are virtual ways to bring that learning into your home.

post_text:
San Diego County Office of Education staff and PASS AmeriCorps members helped Warner Unified School District organize and prepare free meals for students last week. Staying six feet apart and following the latest health and safety guidelines, these volunteers got to see the caring and personal touch of district and school staff members up close.
Thank you to all of the school staff members across the county making thousands of meals each day so that children from age 2-18 won't go hungry during school closures.

üçèFind local school meal sites at https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/20-03-13-student-food-service-during-district-closures.aspx or download the CA Meals for Kids app at https://www.cde.ca.gov/re/mo/cameals.asp.

Kids for Peace has free online projects for kids of all ages to discover purposeful activities during #COVID19 school closures. Find fresh ways for students to connect with other kids, care for the elderly, thank our healthcare workers, celebrate birthdays safely, and send love out to the world.
Some examples include:
ü§© Surprise delivery drivers with a gratitude gift. Place a note and a gift of food, water, gift cards, a toilet paper roll, etc. in a basket by your front door. #ThankYourDeliveryDriver.

üíô Sew face masks for nurses and doctors.
üôå Do household chores without being asked - make your bed, pick up your toys, clean your room/bathroom.

post_text:
Being a teenager is tough. That's especially true when there's a pandemic closing schools, canceling events, and postponing or skipping some of the biggest moments. Add in the loss of everyday interactions, like chatting with friends and interacting with teachers and school staff, and this is a really difficult time to be a young person.
Teens who are feeling stressed, isolated, and depressed, you are not alone. And if you have a friend feeling this way, you can help. Find support and strategies for self-care in the attached images. Share. Tag a friend. We're in this together.

#COVID19 #mentalhealthmatters #highschool #juniorhigh #middleschool #students #teachers #inittogether #togetherathome #SanDiegoCounty #teenmentalhealth

post_text:
What will grading look like with distance learning? Will the #Classof2020 be able to graduate? What about college admissions?
The California Department of Education has a new FAQ with guidance on grading and graduation requirements during COVID-19 that address a lot of these concerns.
1:45 p.m UPDATE: In a joint letter from California's K-12 and higher education communities, colleges say they will re-evaluate students' financial needs and financial aid eligibility, and will accept credit/no credit in lieu of a letter grade in A-G courses. Full letter and other details are at https://www.cde.ca.gov/ls/he/hn/collegereqsinformation.asp.

Learn more at the link below. Updates will also be posted at this site.

#COVID19 #schoolclosures #SanDiegoCounty #graduation #college #grades
https://www.cde.ca.gov/ls/he/hn/gradegraduationfaq.asp

post_text:
The mental health effects of COVID-19 are as important to address as the physical health effects. This is especially true for the one in five who already have mental health conditions ‚Äì or the one in two who are at risk of developing them.

Be sure to take time this weekend to take care of yourself - take a break from the news, get some fresh air, talk to a friend - so you can help your child through this time. Here are some ways you can create a safe emotional and physical environment for your student.

Find more resources at https://covid-19.sdcoe.net/Parent-Resources.

#StayHome #InItTogether #COVID19 #ParentResources #MentalHealthMatters

Educators, we know you're burning the candle at both ends during #COVID19 school closures. In the midst of this pandemic, you're caring for your family and keeping up with your students. SDCOE teams have been working to support you. We have instructional resources categorized by content area at covid-19.sdcoe.net, and this week SDCOE launched free innovative distance learning webinars. Now, Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., there's live professional learning designed for what you need now. Be sure to take care of your own professional learning needs. View the courses on tap for this week and all the details at
https://sdcoe.instructure.com/courses/682.
#selfcare #schoolclosures #stayathome #keeplearning #togetherathome #professionallearning #fillyourcup #students #teachers

post_text:
San Diego County families looking for child care can call 1-800-481-2151 to discuss their child care needs with an advisor, who will complete a specialized search to identify the licensed child care options. Advisors will call providers on the family‚Äôs behalf to see which providers have open slots and may meet their needs best.

With schools across the county closed, and the Governor suggesting it is unlikely they will reopen before summer break, YMCA of San Diego County Childcare Resource Service (CRS) is helping families in need of child care find the options that might work for their families.

#covid19 #schoolclosures #sandiegocounty
https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/YMCA-Childcare-Resource-Service-Providing-Enhanced-Child-Care-Referrals.aspx

post_text:
There are free internet opportunities for families with students through local broadband providers.
Cox Communications - California - San Diego - San Diego is offering one month of free service for new Connect2Compete customers (regular $10 a month).
Charter Communications, which operates Spectrum broadband brand, is offering free Internet for 60 days to new customers with K-12 and college students at home.
Also, AT&T and T-Mobile are removing data usage caps, which can lead to overage charges. Verizon is following the FCC guidelines by eliminating late fees and committing not to terminate service if households are unable pay.
Call your local provider for details.

#COVID19 #keeplearning #stayhome #keepstudentsconnected #keepamericaconnected
shared_text:
SANDIEGOUNIONTRIBUNE.COM

post_text:
We know how difficult these school closures are for working families. But it's important to remember that closing schools is an effort to reduce the number of individuals gathered into a given space to prevent the spread of the virus. While there are still public spaces open and available, San Diego County health officials ask parents to strongly consider keeping their children home or limited to small groups at this time.

Sabemos que el cierre de escuelas es dificil para las familias que trabajan. Pero es importante recordar que el cierre de escuelas es un esfuerzo para reducir la cantidad de personas agrupadas en un solo espacio y prevenir la propagaci√≥n del virus. Aunque a√∫n hay espacios p√∫blicos abiertos, los oficiales de salud p√∫blica del Condado de San Diego les piden a los padres que consideren seriamente mantener a sus hijos en casa o limitarse a grupos peque√±os en este momento.
#socialdistancing #distancelearning #stayhome #watchKPBS #COVIDschoolclosures #COVID19

post_text:
Read and share -- Starting today tune into KPBS 2 for TK-12 educational programming during school closures. It's critical that learning continues for all students in this time of uncertainty, and the San Diego County Office of Education is proud to partner with KPBS and San Diego Unified School District to work to get robust educational materials into the hands of all students.

Launched on Monday, March 16, a new initiative, ‚ÄúAt-Home Learning: Where Children Matter,‚Äù will bring 12 hours of state standards-aligned television programming scheduled by grade level, and free access to a digital library of educational resources for families, students, educators, and the community.

Learn more at https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/KPBS-school-closure-resources.aspx
#distancelearning #schoolclosures #sandiegocountyschools #quarantinelearning #covid19
shared_text:
Educational Content Available on TV, Online During School Closures
Tune into KPBS 2 during school closures for TK-12 educational programming from KPBS, the San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE), and San Diego Unified School District.

Educational Content Available on TV, Online During School Closures

sdcoe.net
text:
Read and share -- Starting today tune into KPBS 2 for TK-12 educational programming during school closures. It's critical that learning continues for all students in this time of uncertainty, and the San Diego County Office of Education is proud to partner with KPBS and San Diego Unified School District to work to get robust educational materials into the hands of all students.

Launched on Monday, March 16, a new initiative, ‚ÄúAt-Home Learning: Where Children Matter,‚Äù will bring 12 hours of state standards-aligned television programming scheduled by grade level, and free access to a digital library of educational resources for families, students, educators, and the community.

Learn more at https://www.sdcoe.net/news/Pages/KPBS-school-closure-resources.aspx
#distancelearning #schoolclosures #sandiegocountyschools #quarantinelearning #covid19

post_text: A big THANK YOU goes out to all school social workers in San Diego County as we celebrate National School Social Work Week. School social workers play a vital role assisting students, teachers, staff, parents, and families in enhancing both school climate and the overall academic mission. They provide social-emotional and mental health support services to students to help alleviate barriers to academic success and improve overall well-being. Take a moment to thank the social workers at your site for their dedication to helping students succeed.

post_text:
National School Counseling Week is the best time to register for the San Diego School Counselor Con! It's the largest local event designed by school counselors for school counselors. The theme for the March 9 event at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront Hotel is Unmasking Potential.

Learn more and register at https://www.sdcoe.net/lls/school-improvement/Pages/School-Counselor-Leadership-Conference.aspx.

Come explore best practices and collaborate with others, learn how to advocate for college and career readiness with your students, and get the support, tools, and resources you need to provide the best service possible for ALL students.
#sdcounselors #sdequity #NSCW2020

shared_text:
San Diego County Office of Education added 31 new photos ‚Äî at Farr Avenue Elementary School - EUSD.
January 23 at 5:10 PM ¬∑ Escondido, CA ¬∑

We had so much fun visiting Live Oak Elementary School in Fallbrook and Farr Avenue Elementary in Escondido today! Special guests 10News anchors Virginia Cha and Derek Staahl, 10News General Manager Leon Clark, and Clifford the Big Red Dog delivered thousands of books to the students in these schools as part of two special assemblies. It was all part of the annual Give a Child a Book campaign, in partnership with the Scripps Howard Foundation.

post_text: Students at Davila Day School had a special guest today! Santa used American Sign Language to communicate w/our students who are Deaf or Hard of hearing. ‚ÄúTo see a Santa that is just like them helps open up their world‚Äù says school audiologist Dr. Amy Kalenderian, one of the staff ‚Äúelves‚Äù who helped coordinate the visit. Thanks Hunter Sowards and KUSI News for coming out today - and shooting this video.
shared_text:
Hunter Sowards
December 20, 2019 at 10:30 AM ¬∑

A moment I will never forget, and one that these students won‚Äôt either. I am at Davila Day School where children who are deaf and hard of hearing got a very special visit from Santa. Santa who knows just how to ask if they‚Äôve been good this year ‚ù§Ô∏è This is truly what Christmas is all about. We‚Äôre live with more on Good Morning San Diego Davila Day School

post_text: It was such an honor to recognize Crawford High senior Tina Tran as the NBC 7 San Diego Inspirational Student of the Month. She‚Äôs overcome adversity to become class president and a star athlete and student. The tears and cheers during the announcement made it clear how much Tina‚Äôs classmates support and admire her. One classmate said that Tina is inspiring because she shows her that you ‚Äúcan do anything in life. No matter how far behind you get, you can always catch up.‚Äù Congratulations, Tina! San Diego Unified School District

Feeling especially thankful today? Turn that feeling into action by nominating someone in your life who's making a difference for students with an SDCOE Lighthouse Award. Help celebrate a champion for #educationalequity in your school, district, or community at the Equity Conference 2020! (And while you're looking for that perfect gift for family and friends on #BlackFriday, check out the Equity Conference 2020 on Jan. 16-17 for yourself! Register today.)

post_text:
Hey, History-Social Science educators, your favorite annual event is finally open for registration! Treat yourself this holiday season with an event that's designed just for you. The 2020 SDCOE History-Social Science Conference is Feb. 11 and it's focused on the alignment to the Environmental Principles and Concepts in the state framework. Sessions will explore themes of interactions between humans and the environment.
You know that's just what you've been looking for! So go now, register for the event and take advantage of the discounted price! https://www.sdcoe.net/lls/ccr/Pages/history-pro-development.aspx
#civicengagement #history #socialscience #historyandtheenvironment #humanimpact #K12 #caedchat

post_text: Displaying the same calmness that makes her a great teacher, Fallbrook STEM Academy's Mandy Geminert really was excited when we recognized her this week as the NBC 7 San Diego Inspirational Teacher of the Month. Her favorite part about being an educators is learning things to help her students and seeing the ah-ha moments when things finally click with them Thanks to sponsors Mathnasium and NBC 7 San Diego for their support in honoring great teachers!

post_text:
Congratulations to Fallbrook High's Emiliano Corona, our most recent Nbcsandiego.com Inspirational Student of the Month! Always a special day when you get to recognize a student who is humble, happy, helpful, and hard working and, according to his counselor, the smartest student she's seen in her 13 years. Emiliano's key to success? He says to "keep putting your mind to it. Don't let other people bring you down. If you think that you're right in your heart and in your soul, you probably are right." Congrats, Emiliano!
#sandiegocountystudents
#students
#studentrecognition
#studentsuccess
#inspirational
#sdcoe
#fallbrookUHSD
#nbcsandiego
#rorydevine

post_text: It's always nice when a dedicated member of #TeamSDCOE is recognized for having an impact on the community!
shared_text:
SDCOE.NET
Outdoor Education Employee Receives Local Council‚Äôs President‚Äôs Award

Cuyamaca Outdoor School
October 28, 2019 at 9:23 AM ¬∑

The students who attend Cuyamaca Outdoor School never get to meet Faith Mitchell, but they benefit from her work all the same. We're proud she was honored by the Community Campership Council, Inc.!
text:

post_text:
The #MillerFire is burning in Valley Center. Valley Center High School is no longer in shelter in place and they're in the process of transporting students off campus.

For those following the #Sawday fire, Ramona Unified schools remain open. All students are being kept inside due to the poor air quality, but school is still in session.

That being said, schools in Dehesa School District, Julian Union High School District, Julian Union School District, Mountain Empire Unified School District, Spencer Valley School District, and Warner Unified School District are closed today, Friday, Oct. 25. Double Peak Elementary in San Marcos Unified is also closed.

post_text:
SDCOE is hosting a free Census 2020 curriculum training on Oct. 14 from 8:30 a.m. to 3 p.m.

The curriculum modules -- developed by the Sacramento County Office of Education in partnership with the Los Angeles County Office of Education -- are designed to teach students at the 5th-, 8th-, 11th-, and 12th-grade levels about the US Census and get them excited to advocate for a complete count in 2020.

Participants will receive breakfast and lunch, as well as all the resources you need to make teaching about the census easy.

Register now!

post_text:
Nearly all parents say they want their child to study computer science, but the majority of schools don't teach it. Let's help all students move from passive computer users to active participants -- check out SDCOE's new computer science workshops for administrators and teachers! Based on the new state Computer Science Standards, these workshops are held throughout the county. Details at www.sdcoe.net/CS.
#CS4All Computer Science Education Week #SDEquity #EducationalEquity #computerscience
